error.signature: cannot use x (variable of type T) as type U in argument

verdict.summary: Go strict type system rejects assignment or argument because types don't match, even if they're structurally similar.

dead_ends.action: Using unsafe.Pointer to convert between types
dead_ends.why_fails: Bypasses type safety; leads to memory corruption if types differ

dead_ends.action: Adding type conversion without checking compatibility
dead_ends.why_fails: Some conversions compile but lose data (e.g., int64 to int32)

workarounds.action: Use explicit type conversion: U(x) if the types are convertible
workarounds.how: Go allows conversion between compatible types like int32(x) or string(b)

workarounds.action: Implement the required interface on the type
workarounds.how: If the target is an interface, add the missing methods to your type

frequently_confused_with.distinction: 'cannot use x (variable of type T) as type U in argument' indicates a type mismatch in an argument or assignment, while 'panic' indicates an invalid interface type assertion.
